title: Terminal Help
text:
A command-line interface is a means of interacting with software via text formatted inputs. A program that implements such a text interface is called a command-line interpreter, command processor, or shell. The various Unix shells include sh, ksh, csh, tcsh, zsh, Bash, etc. The Macintosh operating system macOS is based on a Unix-like operating system. By running the emulator program called Terminal, a Mac user can access a Unix-like command-line interface. To access navigate to /System/Applications/Utilities/Terminal.app.


The following is a brief description of the shell’s operation when it reads and executes a command. Basically, the shell does the following:

Reads its input from a file or from the user’s terminal.
Breaks the input into words and operators, obeying the quoting rules and performs alias expansion. These tokens are separated by metacharacters.
Parses the tokens into simple and compound commands.
Performs the various shell expansions, breaking the expanded tokens into lists of filenames and commands and arguments.
Performs any necessary redirections and removes the redirection operators and their operands from the argument list.
Executes the command.
Optionally waits for the command to complete and collects its exit status.




command [arguments]

command is a utility or program function.
arguments are parameters, inputs, or options (if any) used by the command function.


Example 1Example 2


man man
The man command displays manual documentation pages. In this example, it displays the manual for the man command. Enter q to exit the manual.


pwd
Not all commands have or need arguments. The pwd command returns the present working directory.




flags are a class of argument with a single or double hyphen prefix.




Option
Description




-[short_flags]
May be consecutive or combined


--[long_flags]
Descriptive but can’t be combined




Example 1Example 2


git --version
Git is a free and open source distributed version control system. The long flag --version prints the Git suite version that the git program came from.


ls
ls -a
ls -a -l
ls -al
The ls command lists directory contents. The short flag -a indicates the ls command will include hidden directory contents names that begin with a dot. The short flag -l indicates the ls command will list files in long format.






A character that, when unquoted, separates words.



newline
End of execution operator


|
Pipe operator


&
Asynchronous list termination operator


;
Sequential list termination operator


( )
Group list operator


<
Input redirect operator


>
Output redirect operator


#
Comment






Operators contain at least one unquoted metacharacter.


A token that performs a control function.



|
Sequence commands in pipeline


     |&
Pipe shorthand for 2>&1 |


&
Execute command in the background


;
End line


&&
Logical AND list operator


||
Logical OR list operator


     ;;
Case statement termination


     ;&
Case statement termination


     ;;&
Case statement termination


( )
Create a subshell grouping









<
Input redirect operator


>
Output redirect operator


     >|



<<
Here-document redirect


     <<-
Here-document strip leading tab characters


<<<
Here-strings redirect


>>
Output append operator


<&
Duplicate input file descriptor


>&
Duplicate output file descriptor


     <&-
Input file descriptor mover


     >&-
Output file descriptor mover


<>
Open File descriptor







A character that, when unquoted, separates words.







for
Looping Construct


while
Looping Construct


until
Looping Construct


if
Conditional Construct


select
Conditional Construct


case
Conditional Construct


[[   ]]
Conditional Expression expression


(( ))
Conditional Arithmetic expression


( )
Grouping list (subshell environment)


{ ; }
Grouping list (current shell environment)


     in
Compound Construct (case, select, or for)


     do
Compound Construct (for, while, select, or until )


     done
Looping Compound Construct (for, while, or until )


     then
Conditional Compound Construct (if)


     elif
Conditional Compound Construct (if)


     else
Conditional Compound Construct (if)


     fi
Conditional Compound Construct (if)


     esac
Conditional Compound Construct (case)


coproc
Coprocesses (compound asynchronous execution)


time
Timing statistic


function
Compound Grouping Function


!
Bang



Escape Character A non-quoted backslash ’’ is the Bash escape character. It preserves the literal value of the next character that follows, removing any special meaning it has, with the exception of newline.
Special Parameters The shell treats several parameters specially. These parameters may only be referenced; assignment to them is not allowed.



$*



$@



$#



$-



$$



$!



$0







%
Modulus operator


&&
Logical AND


||
Logical OR


!
Logical NOT






*
Wild card


?
Single character wild card


[…]
Bracket expression



Within a bracket expression, character classes can be specified using the syntax [:class:], where class is one of the following classes defined in the POSIX standard:



[:alnum:]



[:alpha:]



[:ascii:]



[:blank:]



[:cntrl:]



[:digit:]



[:graph:]



[:lower:]



[:print:]



[:punct:]



[:space:]



[:upper:]



[:word:]



[:xdigit:]










/
Root directory


.
Current directory


..
Parent directory


~
Home directory ($HOME)


~+
present working directory ($PWD)


~-
previous present working directory

title: Terminal Help
text:
Control Keystrokes

Movement



Ctrl + a
Move cursor to start of line


Ctrl + e
Move cursor to end of line


Ctrl + b
Cursor back (left) one character


     Left Arrow



Ctrl + f
Cursor forward (right) one character


     Left Arrow



Ctrl + xx
Jump to start of line and toggle back again


Opt + Left Arrow
Jump one word back


Opt + Right Arrow
Jump one word forward





Edit



Ctrl + i
Auto complete command


     Tab



Ctrl + h
Backspace


     Delete



Ctrl + d
Forward delete character under cursor


     Fn + Delete



Ctrl + w
Cut one word before cursor to clipboard


     Esc + Delete



Ctrl + k
Cut line after cursor to clipboard


Ctrl + u
Cut line to clipboard


Ctrl + y
Paste from clipboard (a.k.a yank)


Ctrl + -
Undo


Ctrl + l
Clear terminal screen


     Cmd + k



     clear + ENTER



Cmd + l
Clear screen of previous command





Process



Ctrl + j
Enter


Ctrl + c
Cancel a command (interrupt)


Ctrl + g
Abort current action and ring bell


Ctrl + s
Stop command output


Ctrl + g
Resume command output


Ctrl + q
Cancel a command (interrupt)


Ctrl + d
Exit terminal


     exit + ENTER






History



Ctrl + p
Show previous command


     Up Arrow



Ctrl + n
Show next command


     Down Arrow



Ctrl + r
Search within previous commands





Misc.



Ctrl + t
Transpose previous two characters


Esc + t
Transpose previous two words


Esc + u
UPPER capitalize under cursor to end of word


Esc + l
lower capitalize under cursor to end of word


Esc + c
Sentence capitalize under cursor to end of word

title: Terminal Help
text:
Common commands

System Info



whoami
Show current user name


who
Show who is on the system


id -un
Show user identity


w
Show who is logged in and what they are doing


date
Show current time and date


cal
Show current calendar


echo $SHELL
Show name of shell interpreter


echo $USER
Show name of current user


echo $HOME
Show home directory of current user


     echo ~



echo $PWD
Show path of current working directory


echo $PATH
Show list of directories shell will search through


printenv
Show list of all environment variables





System Navigation







pwd
Show current directory stack from root


dirs
Show current directory stack from home


ls
List current directory contents


cd [directory_path]
Change current directory to new path location


     cd
Change current directory to home


     cd ~



     cd ..
Change current directory to parent directory


     cd ../..
Change current directory to grandparent directory


     cd /
Change current directory to root


     cd -
Change current directory to previous directory


find [directory] -name [object]
Find the location of an object





File Manipulation







Option
Description




open [path]
Open a file, directory, or URL


mkdir [directory]
Create a new directory


     mkdir -p [directory_path]



touch [file_name(s)]
Create a new file


cp [source_file]   [target_file]
Copy a file from one directory to another


mv [source_file] [target_file]
Move/rename a file from one directory to another


ln -s [source_path] [sym_name]
Create a symbolic link


rm [file]
Remove a file


     rm -i [file]
Remove a file but request confirmation


     rm -r [directory]
Remove a directory


     rm -rf [directory]
Remove a file without confirmation prompts


     rm ./*
Remove everything in current directory (Caution!)


cat [file_names]
Print the file contents


     cat >> [file_name] ENTER [text] Ctrl + D
Append text to file


     cat [source_file] >> [target_file]
Append file contents to file


     cat > [file_name] ENTER [text] Ctrl + D
Create a new file and add file text


> [file_name] ENTER [text] Ctrl + D
Overwrite file text


echo [text] > [file_name]
Write text to file


     echo [text] >> [file_name]
Append text to file


less [file_name]



head [file_name]



tail [file_name]



nano [file_name]






History



Option
Description




history
List command history index


     ![index_number]
Rerun command by history index number


     !!
Run the last command again


     !-[number]
Rerun command n lines back


     ![string]
Rerun last command starting with string

title: Terminal Help
text:
Misc.



Option
Description




grep



printf



tar



gzip



tmux



ssh



sudo



bc
Basic calculator


     quit
Exit calculator


bc <<< ‘[expression]’
In line basic calculator


expr [expression]
Direct expression evaluation


echo $(( [expression] ))





Special Parameters



Option
Description




$([command])
Command substitution


$(( expression ))
Arithmetic expression evaluation


[command] &
Run command in background
